data: Marble plaque, set in plaster in modern times.
Letters with serifs, rhomboid Ο and Φ, angular cursive Ω at l. 5 (as a flipped Μ); ος at l. 2, τη at l. 3, ος and ρων at l. 5 in ligature. Triangle-shaped interpuncts at ll. 3, 4, 5, 6.
Ferrara states 'found at Catania', but this remains uncertain
Observed by Torremuzza and Kaibel in Museo Biscari, later by Korhonen in magazzino del Cortile, Collezione Biscari, formerly sala VI, 97.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Castello Ursino, Piazza Federico II di Svevia, 95121 Catania (CT)

Kalle Korhonen, Le iscrizioni del Museo civico di Catania : storia delle collezioni, cultura epigrafica, edizione (Helsinki: Societas Scientiarum Fennica, 2004)

Motivi di religiosità pagana nei mosaici di Piazza Armerina

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text based on photographs;
  • line.5: Franz: πατρῶνι; Manganaro interpreted Πάτρων as a proper name

English translation

Marta Fogagnolo

Saboukis Kallimorphos, lived for 32 years. Saboukis Zoilos, his patron (made this).

Italian translation

Marta Fogagnolo

Saboukis Kallimorphos visse 32 anni. Saboukis Zoilos, suo patrono (realizzò questo).

commentary

The epitaph presents the traditional structure with the name of the deceased, the indication of his age (with the verb ζάω in the aorist form) and a second sentence with the name of the dedicant in the nominative form and the dedication verb (ποιέω in the aorist form). The formulae and the palaeography are characteristic of Catania and of a 2nd-century CE dating, according to Korhonen (2004: 229; contra Manganaro 1959: 242, who dated the inscription to the 4th cent. CE). The epitaph was dedicated to a libertus Saboukis Kallimorphos by his patron Saboukis Zoilos (πάτρων is not part of the proper name of the dedicant, as Manganaro suggested: see J. and L. Robert, BE 1961: 268 nr. 861). The patron belonged to the gens Sabucia, who seems to have owned several latifundia in Sicily, as numerous toponyms attest: see Manganaro 1959.

Σαβοῦκις Καλλίμορφος ἔζησεν · ἔτη · · λβ · Σαβούκις · Ζωίλος · πάτρων · ἐποίησε ·
Text based on photographs Franz: πατρῶνι; Manganaro interpreted Πάτρων as a proper name

Saboukis Kallimorphos, lived for 32 years. Saboukis Zoilos, his patron (made this).

Saboukis Kallimorphos visse 32 anni. Saboukis Zoilos, suo patrono (realizzò questo).

The epitaph presents the traditional structure with the name of the deceased, the indication of his age (with the verb ζάω in the aorist form) and a second sentence with the name of the dedicant in the nominative form and the dedication verb (ποιέω in the aorist form). The formulae and the palaeography are characteristic of Catania and of a 2nd-century CE dating, according to Korhonen (2004: 229; contra Manganaro 1959: 242, who dated the inscription to the 4th cent. CE). The epitaph was dedicated to a libertus Saboukis Kallimorphos by his patron Saboukis Zoilos (πάτρων is not part of the proper name of the dedicant, as Manganaro suggested: see J. and L. Robert, BE 1961: 268 nr. 861). The patron belonged to the gens Sabucia, who seems to have owned several latifundia in Sicily, as numerous toponyms attest: see Manganaro 1959.
